content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly used the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student is given the task of determining the molar concentration of a <math alttext="C u S O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> solution using two different procedures, precipitation and spectrophotometry. For the precipitation experiment, the student adds <math alttext="20.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.200 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="B a, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Ba</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The reaction goes to completion, and a white precipitate forms. The student filters the precipitate and dries it overnight. The data are given in the following table. Mass of dry filter paper <math alttext="0.764 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.764</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Volume of <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Volume of <math alttext="0.200 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="B a, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Ba</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="20.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Mass of filter paper and dried precipitate <math alttext="1.136 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.136</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Write a balanced net ionic equation for the precipitation reaction.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly used the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student is given the task of determining the molar concentration of a <math alttext="C u S O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> solution using two different procedures, precipitation and spectrophotometry. For the precipitation experiment, the student adds <math alttext="20.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.200 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="B a, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Ba</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The reaction goes to completion, and a white precipitate forms. The student filters the precipitate and dries it overnight. The data are given in the following table. Mass of dry filter paper <math alttext="0.764 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.764</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Volume of <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="50.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Volume of <math alttext="0.200 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="B a, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Ba</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="20.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Mass of filter paper and dried precipitate <math alttext="1.136 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.136</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Write a balanced net ionic equation for the precipitation reaction.
(b) Calculate the number of moles of precipitate formed.

(c) Calculate the molarity of the original <math alttext="C u S O 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> solution.

For the spectrophotometry experiment, the student first makes a standard curve. The student uses a <math alttext="0.1000 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.1000</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> to make three more solutions of known concentration (<math alttext="0.0500 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="0.0300 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0300</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="0.0100 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) in <math alttext="50.00 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> volumetric flasks.(d) Calculate the volume of <math alttext="0.1000 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.1000</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> needed to make <math alttext="50.00 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.0500 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>.

(e) Briefly describe the procedure the student should follow to make <math alttext="50.00 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.0500 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> using <math alttext="0.1000 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.1000</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, a <math alttext="50.00 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> volumetric flask, and other standard laboratory equipment. Assume that all appropriate safety precautions will be taken.

The standard curve is given below. (f) The absorbance of the <math alttext="C u S O 4" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> solution of unknown concentration is <math alttext="0.219" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.219</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Determine the molarity of the solution.

(g) A second student performs the same experiment. There are a few drops of water in the cuvette before the second student adds the <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of unknown concentration. Will this result in a <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CuSO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> concentration for the unknown that is greater than, less than, or equal to the concentration determined in part (f)? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.C: Identify experimental procedures that are aligned to a scientific question (which may include a sketch of a lab setup).
